I think there are a few areas where the Catholic Church needs to modernize its views. I believe that the Church's stance on several issues is one of the reasons it's losing followers. They've been saying that they're losing followers, and I think it's because they're not very accepting of certain things. 

For example, their views on gay marriages, abortions, and birth control are quite strict. While I understand that these are important issues, I think their views are a bit outdated in some ways. If they adapted to a more contemporary way of thinking, I think they'd be less concerned about losing their followers.

However, it seems like a lot of people are starting to distance themselves from the Church due to their stance on these issues. They see the Church's views as being out of touch with modern society, which is causing disagreements and divisions. 

The Church's opposition to abortion, for instance, might make it difficult for people who support it to feel comfortable being part of the Church. Similarly, those who believe in gay marriage might not want to be part of a community that views it as wrong. The same goes for other issues like the exclusion of female priests and married priests.

Personally, I don't see why priests can't be married or have female priests. The Church claims that priests are devoted to God, but everyone else in the world has to balance their job with other aspects of their life, so why should priests be any different? It's not like having a family or other relationships would distract them from their faith.

Honestly, I haven't really had much to say on the topic of gay marriage, but I do have a pretty clear opinion on it. In my view, being gay isn't something that someone chooses, it's just who they are. I don't think people should be held accountable for their sexual orientation, and it's not something that's within their control.

To me, it seems unfair that people can marry someone of the opposite sex, but not someone of the same sex. It just doesn't seem right to me. I've given it some thought, but to be honest, I haven't put a lot of effort into it because it just seems like a basic issue of equality.

Like, we're all born with our own unique qualities and characteristics - some people are straight, while others are gay. It's not something that people can just decide or choose to be. I think it's unfair to hold gay people to a different standard just because of who they are.

I don't think the federal government has any business getting involved in this issue. It's not a matter of national security, and it's not a moral issue in my opinion. It's just a matter of people being who they are and living their lives. I don't think the government should be able to dictate who people can and can't marry based on their own personal preferences.

It's hard to put into words, but it just seems like the government is overstepping its bounds when it comes to this issue. They're not addressing any real concerns or threats to society, they're just interfering with people's personal lives. And that's not right.

I think that's all I have to say on the matter.

I think that gay marriage should be legalized. The main reason for this is that there isn't a valid argument against it. Many people believe that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but this is a misconception. The fact is that gay couples are vastly different from straight couples, and it's impossible to compare the two. They're like two sides of the same coin - they're fundamentally the same, but with some key differences. It's not like one is inherently better than the other.

One of the biggest issues is that gay couples are denied certain civil rights, such as the right to make medical decisions for each other or visit each other in the hospital. This is ridiculous, especially since many gay couples are committed to each other for life. Research has shown that homosexual couples have the same rates of success and satisfaction as heterosexual couples, and they have the same factors that contribute to a healthy relationship.

The real issue here is that gay couples are asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government, not a church wedding. If we're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are the same in many ways, including the roles they play in their relationships, and they're just as capable of raising children as straight couples.

People worry about adoption and community issues, but these concerns are unfounded. Children of gay couples are just as likely to adjust to society as children of straight couples, and they're not more likely to be influenced by their parents' sexual orientation. The real issue is how children of gay couples are treated by their peers and other adults in society. In cities like New York, for example, children of gay parents have to deal with bullying and harassment in public schools.

It's not about the parenting skills of gay couples, but about the societal attitudes towards them. It's not about whether or not children of gay couples will turn out okay, but about whether or not society will accept and support them. The federal government should be involved in making gay marriage legal nationwide, and the proposed amendment should be rejected. President Bush's views on the matter are rooted in his own moral beliefs, but morality varies from person to person, and it's not up to the government to impose its own morality on the rest of the country.

Many people are against gay marriage because they believe that gay people are psychologically damaged or have a personality defect. However, this is simply not true. The American Psychological Association has stated that these claims are unfounded, and people should listen to research and studies rather than popular opinion or cultural norms. By doing so, we can start to see the world in a different light.

Okay, so, I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer. People often assume that just because a drug is prohibited, it automatically has no benefits. But, in my opinion, that's not necessarily true. I'd say that for public availability, I'm against it, no question. However, for medical purposes, I believe it's a different story. A drug's illegality doesn't necessarily mean it's not beneficial. It's not beneficial in some cases, but I think you get my point.

Yeah, I mean think about it, there are plenty of controlled substances that pharmacies use all the time, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets. They're prescribed because of their benefits, even though they're restricted. If we deny the benefits of marijuana just because of the stigma surrounding it, well, that doesn't make sense to me. I think we should acknowledge its potential benefits instead.

I don't think it's that similar to alcohol, since marijuana abuse can have different consequences. Although, like with alcohol, abusing it can lead to problems. It's a complex issue. I'd say we could integrate it into our society gradually, but not all at once, as that could lead to abuse. However, if we could just remove the stigma around marijuana, people might use it more responsibly.

People have this horrible image of marijuana because it's a prohibited substance, but it's not as bad for you as heroin or cocaine. If we could change this perception, people might be more likely to use it responsibly, especially for medicinal purposes.

I think the church has already made some changes to adapt to the 21st century. The atmosphere isn't as strict as it was when I was younger. I used to attend church every Sunday and would always dress up in cute little dresses, matching shoes, and a matching purse. That was just part of the routine, especially since I went to a private school where I'd see my friends every weekend. However, as I've gotten older, they've introduced a more casual teenage mass that lasts only 30 minutes. People now wear a lot more relaxed clothing, especially during the summer months when some even show up directly from the beach. Even during morning masses, which I used to dress up for, people often wear jeans and khakis, a far cry from the more formal attire of the past. To me, that's the biggest change I've noticed. 

As for other issues, like the allegations against Catholic priests regarding pedophilia, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented these incidents. There are married men who still develop pedophilic tendencies, and it's not solely because they're allowed or not allowed to get married. It's the individual's choice to become a priest, and their attraction to young children isn't something that can be prevented by changing the church's stance on marriage. In fact, some religions already allow their clergy to get married, like Seventh Heaven's reverend or minister, so it's not a matter of whether they're allowed to get married, but rather a personal choice. 

I believe that pedophilia is largely based on genetics, and people are born with these tendencies. It's not something that's developed due to upbringing or environment. While there might be some factors that contribute to it, I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent these incidents from happening. If they knew about the abuse and were covering it up, then that's a different story, but in many cases, they might not have been aware. 

That's my take on the Catholic Church. I don't have any further thoughts to add.

What got me going is that I think the initial premise was somewhat plausible, but the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks was still too raw, and I believe it was used as a pretext for the invasion of Iraq. The Bush administration initially linked Iraq to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein possessed WMDs, which we now know was a false narrative. This really put my hackles up, and the whole Iraq war still boils my blood.

It's hard to shake the feeling that the Bush administration deliberately misled the American public and hasn't owned up to it. Even Colin Powell, who presented the evidence at the UN, has since admitted he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time. To me, that's a severe breach of trust, and I think it's an impeachable offense to lie to the American people like that.

The Bush administration's disregard for the constitution has been evident since 9/11, and it's been a long-term strategy to marginalize it. I believe they had a plan to go to war from the start, driven by a personal vendetta against Saddam Hussein, possibly stemming from his father's administration.

The alleged plan to expand our energy supply in the region, as revealed by a former Treasury Secretary in his book, adds fuel to the fire. It's an underhanded way to achieve this goal.

While I think the war has gone on long enough, I'm not convinced it's the right time to withdraw, as it could lead to civil war and more casualties. The current alternative, which involves a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia, might not be the solution either, as it could create more problems in the long run. Iraq's sovereignty is at risk, and the interim government is struggling to maintain control.

The news reports suggest that the Parliament is ineffective, and even the Prime Minister has limited control over the political process. The return of radical elements like Muqtada al-Sadr's party, which now holds 20 seats in the Iraqi Parliament, is a significant concern. The political process is plagued by infighting and radical factions vying for control, making it a challenging and fractious environment.

I'm at a loss for words to articulate my frustrations in polite company.

I've been trying to think about the War in Iraq, but to be honest, it's a bit of a tough topic for me. I mean, it's not even like it was officially declared as a war, you know? It feels like we just sort of went after Iraq as a way of getting back at them for the 9/11 attacks. So, I haven't really been following it closely, I don't know the details, and I'm not sure what our main goals are anymore. I think we're trying to build democracy over there, but it feels like that's just a way of making Iraq like us, and we're also sort of using it as an excuse to get control of their oil resources. However, I don't think that's a good enough reason to keep sending our troops over there, because it's causing so much tension and hurting innocent people. It's like, if we stay, we'll have to try to create democracy, but that's going to take forever, and if we leave, they'll be angry with us for messing things up. I'm really not sure what to think.

Honestly, I think the whole thing is kind of pointless now. I'm not even sure why we're still calling it a war when it was never officially declared by Congress. I think that's like, a requirement or something. And I'm not sure what our point is anymore. We're using guns to show that we're powerful and American, but I don't think that's a good enough reason to keep going. I think we should just call it what it is and try to find a way to get out of there without causing more harm.

But at the same time, I feel bad for the families of our soldiers who are over there, and I don't want them to get hurt. And it's hard to say that I want the war to end when I know that it's affecting so many people's lives. However, I do think that trying to impose our values and culture on Iraq is just going to make things worse for them in the long run. It's a whole different culture over there, and we're just going to end up causing more problems by trying to change them. And I think that's what's going to make the Al-Kaida thing even worse, and they'll just keep hating us more. So, I think this whole thing is just going to drag on for years and years.

Honestly, I have some reservations about the notion that it's right for the government to declare something as legal or illegal, especially when it comes to issues that are largely under the purview of churches. The separation of church and state is a cornerstone principle in the US constitution, and I believe that trying to impose a particular stance on this issue would be a clear disregard for that fundamental principle.

In my view, attempting to legislate or enforce powers over these matters would be akin to defying the constitution and its guarantees of separation. Moreover, I think that trying to outlaw something based on the prevailing views of one church or denomination over another would be problematic, given that different churches have varying stances on the issue.

The fact that some churchgoers, like Catholics, are opposed to the practice while others support it, further underscores the idea that it's not for the government to decide what's allowed or prohibited. The separation of church and state is essential for fostering religious tolerance in the US, and any attempt to amend the constitution to restrict this principle would be contradictory to its original intent.

In fact, I think that such an amendment would be one of the few instances where the government would be restricting individual freedoms rather than limiting its own power. I strongly believe that the government should not be involved in this issue, especially when the push for an amendment seems to be driven by personal views rather than a genuine concern for the welfare of the country.

To me, it's hard to see how an amendment banning the practice would have a tangible impact on the economy or society. In fact, it's possible that it could have a positive effect by allowing individuals to make their own choices and decisions. Ultimately, I think it's up to the churches to decide this issue, not the government or any particular individual with a personal agenda.

I've been meaning to share my thoughts on the war in Iraq, but I've been putting it off because I think the government didn't entirely be truthful with the American people about the reasons for the invasion. In my opinion, they tried to link the war in Iraq to the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but the two are not closely related. The government played on the emotions of the American people, who were still reeling from the effects of 9/11, and that's when the invasion of Iraq began in 2003.

As someone who's generally against war, especially when it comes to preemptive strikes, I think the war in Iraq is eerily similar to the Vietnam War in many ways. The US government should have learned from past mistakes, but instead, they seem to be repeating them. A huge number of American soldiers have lost their lives, which is absolutely tragic, and it's not just about the human cost – it's also about the fact that the US government wasn't prepared for the aftermath of removing a country's government. The resulting power vacuum and chaos were predicted, but it seems the government didn't take these consequences into consideration.

The goal was to install a democratic government in Iraq, something that was also attempted in Vietnam. However, the US government should have known that imposing a democracy on a foreign country is never an easy task, especially when faced with a large number of insurgents who are determined to resist. Fighting a war against a country's citizens is a much harder and more complex task than fighting a traditional army. 

In my opinion, the US government was not well-prepared for this situation, and they tried to deceive the American people into believing that the war would be a quick and easy victory. We've been in Iraq for over a decade now, and many American troops are still dying, and we're still training the Iraqi troops to police their own country – a process that will likely take years. It's clear that the US government underestimated the difficulty of implementing a new form of government and making it successful.

Looking back at our own history, democracy was a long and difficult struggle to achieve in the US, with periods of civil war and tension. It's naive to think that the same process would be easy for another country. The US government made it seem like a relatively simple task, but in reality, it's a complex and difficult process.

As for what to do now, it's a tough decision because we've been in Iraq for so long. It's hard to abandon the people we've taken responsibility for, but the cost in American lives and resources is becoming increasingly high. One of the main reasons we invaded Iraq was the promise of a democratic Iraq, but if that's the case, why aren't we doing the same for other countries? I believe the real reason is the oil issue – it's all about control and resources.

It's also worth noting that before the invasion, the US government claimed Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, but no such weapons were ever found. Meanwhile, countries like North Korea, which are known to possess such weapons, are not being targeted. It's clear that the US government is not being thorough or truthful in its decision-making process.

I can only hope that the war in Iraq ends soon and that there will be peace in the country. Unfortunately, that seems unlikely.

I'm a bit stammering here, but let's get to it – I'm for gay marriage. I've always been, to be honest. I genuinely believe it's a personal preference, and research has shown that it's more biological than sociological. It's not something people have control over, so it's inhumane to deny them rights due to it. As someone who's always advocated for gay marriage, I think it's a matter of personal freedom and equality. 

I don't think government or politics should interfere with this issue, as it's a personal, household matter. In my neighborhood, I've seen gay couples living openly, and they function just like any other family – they walk their dogs, go about their daily lives, and deserve the same respect as everyone else. It's ridiculous that Bush is trying to redefine marriage in his own image, disregarding the complexity of the issue.

Research suggests that being gay might be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain, rather than environmental factors like upbringing. For example, someone who grows up with four sisters and no father might not be predisposed to be gay just because of their environment. It's a matter of biology over sociology.

The main issue is that marriage is something people should be able to choose privately, without it being a public spectacle. If a heterosexual couple wants to get married in secret, they can do so without anyone knowing, but gay couples are often forced to deal with media attention. This highlights the stark difference between a private, personal issue and a public, national matter.

To me, it's clear that gay marriage should be a personal, private affair, not something subject to government or national scrutiny.

look, when you publish something online, it's out there for everyone to see 
It's a public forum, after all, and once you put it out, you can't take it back 
As an RA, I've already had to deal with this issue firsthand 
When you share something on the internet, it can paint a certain picture of you in people's minds 
And if you're talking about sensitive topics like violence or harm, someone's going to take notice 
You can't just put that out there for the world to see 
The internet is a public space, and what you post can be seen by anyone, including your friends on Myspace or Facebook 
It's not the school that's monitoring these things, but rather concerned individuals who've noticed something suspicious 
They have to take action because they can't just ignore it, or they might miss an opportunity to prevent something serious from happening 
Of course, it's hard to know what to believe when someone might be joking or just messing around, like in the case we had at our school 
It could be a prank gone wrong, or it could be a genuine warning sign 
The situation we had was that someone overheard a friend making a comment, and when we looked into it, they found some concerning content on their social media profiles 
When you post something online, you're essentially giving up your right to privacy - it's out there for anyone to see 
If you don't want people to know something, don't put it online 
You can't control what people think or how they take what you post 
School officials shouldn't be friending their students on social media, but if they're made aware of something concerning, they have to take it seriously 
It's not an invasion of privacy if it's brought to their attention by someone who's already had access to it 
The problem is that people don't think about the consequences of what they post online - it can be brought to the attention of school officials at any time 
I think it's a good idea for teachers not to have a social media presence, especially if it's under a pseudonym, because then they're trying to keep up appearances 
As an RA, I don't want to know about my residents' personal lives, and I don't want to see their party pictures on Facebook 
I don't think teachers should be friends with their students on social media, and I don't think they should be monitoring their online activity 
It's not our place to know, and it's not our responsibility to police their behavior

Honestly, I think the war has dragged on for far too long. When it first started, the goal was understandable – to establish democracy in a nation that lacked a fair political system. However, it seems like we've lost sight of that original purpose over time. Now, it feels like we're in it just to prove a point, to show the world that we're a powerful nation. I've always questioned the motives behind the war, given the complicated history between George Bush's father and Saddam Hussein.

If the intention was indeed to spread democracy, that would be a valid reason, but only if personal agendas weren't involved. Unfortunately, I believe that's not the case. I think we made our statement in the first few months of the war, but now it's been dragged out for far too long – over a year, in fact. We've had more than enough time to achieve our initial goal.

If we were genuinely trying to bring democracy to a nation ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause for war. However, I believe our reasons have become distorted over time, and we're now fighting for the sake of fighting. It's like we're more invested in the idea of being at war than in achieving a decisive victory or a clear outcome.

I truly believe the war has gone on long enough. At some point, the Iraqi government will have to fend for itself, and I think that time has come. We're draining our economy by spending billions on this war when we have pressing issues on our own turf – poverty, internal conflicts, and infrastructure problems – that desperately need attention and funding. We should be prioritizing these issues instead of throwing money at a war that's lost its purpose.

It's astonishing that we're spending billions and billions of dollars on a war that's not even in our long-term budget. We have real problems that need funding – education, healthcare, public roads, and poverty alleviation. The money would be better spent on addressing these critical issues rather than sacrificing our own citizens in a foreign war that's already lost its cause. I think it's time to acknowledge that.

I'm not sure if I can clarify this, but I was wondering about something. It turns out that someone was able to find out about it because they looked it up online.

Okay, so it's not really an invasion of privacy, right? I mean, if you post stuff on the internet, it's like sharing it with the world. Like on Myspace, you kind of invite people to be your "friend" so they can see your profile. By doing that, you're basically giving them permission to see what you've shared.

Anytime you put something online, you've got to understand that a lot of people are going to see it. So if someone was able to prevent a potentially serious situation from happening because they looked up your online info, that's actually a good thing, right?

However, it's a bit of a tricky situation. On one hand, you can't have someone constantly monitoring everyone's profiles to prevent problems. That would be unfair and discriminatory. On the other hand, if someone was specifically looking for info, they might be trying to do something malicious.

I don't know, I guess it all depends on the situation. If someone was just browsing profiles and happened to find something suspicious, that's one thing. But if they were actively looking for evidence of something, that's different.

Personally, I don't have a Myspace, but I do have a Facebook, and it bothers me that there are people out there who can see all the stuff I've shared. I saw this TV show about a guy who was trying to prove how easily he could get people's info online. He managed to get a girl's screen name and started talking to her on instant messenger within minutes. It's scary to think about.

It's tough because you think people know your interests and other stuff about you, so it's hard to know who's really who online. Even if you limit what you post, there's still a lot of info out there. The thing is, I use Facebook to stay in touch with friends, but it's a trade-off between sharing too much or too little.

I don't know, it's a complicated issue. My roommate was telling me that her high school banned students from having Myspace, which seemed strange to me. I'm not sure how they had the authority to do that.

I guess that's the only other thought I can think of.

hmm, it's been a bit of a struggle to bring myself to talk about the Iraq War again, but it seems like it's one of those topics that can't be avoided. I'm aware that I might sound hypocritical, but I've been thinking a lot about this issue, and I'm not sure I'm comfortable jumping on the bandwagon of people who claim they were opposed to the war from the start. I mean, looking back, it's clear that the majority of people, both in the US and globally, thought the war was a bad idea, except for those within the administration who refused to acknowledge their own mistakes.

I've been following the polls, and it's evident that over 75-80% of the world's population, including Iraqis, US troops, and people from other parts of the globe, think that the war was a disaster. Even the soldiers on the ground consider it a bad idea and think we should withdraw within a year. It's been a complete mess since before we even intervened, and now the idea of pulling out seems just as catastrophic. The Middle East has always been a complex region, and the culture clash between the US and these countries is a significant contributor to our struggles there. It's not that I think Saddam was a good guy - he wasn't - but you have to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's going to turn into a quagmire like it has.

I don't see a good reason to stay in Iraq right now, and I haven't heard a compelling argument from the administration that convinces me otherwise. If they want to withdraw gradually over a year or a bit longer, I'm not opposed to that, but I just don't see any reason to stay any longer than we should. The fact that 80% of Iraqis think we should leave within a year, and at least a quarter of them think we should leave now, makes me wonder if we're listening to the people we're trying to help. I think they might know better than we do, and if we ask them if we should leave, and they say yes, then we can't blame them if things go wrong. It's better to be the ones who made the decision to leave rather than being stuck in a situation where we're not making progress.

You know, I think gender discrimination is still a pretty big issue in the United States. It's not just a women's problem, though; it's more related to the specific field of work you're in. For instance, even though there's supposed to be equality, women often face it tougher because of the "glass ceiling" - it's hard for men to find a job under a woman in charge, mainly because of how society's been raised over time. In the workplace, women might have all the qualifications for a job, but the board might not promote them because historically, women haven't been in leadership positions. 

It's the same with men in certain industries, like being a stay-at-home dad, which is still not common. When a man decides to take on this role, people often look down on him because society expects men to be the breadwinners. It's tough on them because they might want to be involved in raising their kids and helping their partner with their career. 

In the fashion industry, there's another form of discrimination - people often don't take straight men seriously if they're interested in fashion. It's because traditionally, men who like fashion tend to have different lifestyles, and people might question whether they truly understand fashion or not. It's a bit like they're saying, "How can I trust what you know about fashion if you can't even speak like a 'real' woman?" It's weird, I know, but it's a thing.

The thing is, depending on the field of work, there's definitely gender discrimination in society. Changing this is difficult because society has a set mindset, and we've come a long way since the 1800s, but progress is slow. It's happening, though, as women rise to leadership positions and become more accepted in the business world. The same goes for stay-at-home dads - people are starting to realize that maybe the female partner has the better job or wants to be the one working. 

To promote change, you have to show people the good qualities of the people who are usually discriminated against without being too pushy. If you force it, people will resist. I think we're at a good balance now where it's starting to become more accepted. 

It's also worth noting that people from different backgrounds can be discriminated against, not just based on gender, but also based on where they're from or their education level. For instance, someone who grew up on a farm might have poor grammar but be extremely intelligent and work their way up to a CEO position. Other men might look down on them because of their grammar, even though they're incredibly smart. It's another example of how people can be discriminated against based on their background or education level.

To be honest, I'm still trying to figure out whether they legalized it or just decriminalized it. From what I understand, they took it down from a crime to something more like a traffic ticket, where you get cited instead of arrested and booked. While this might seem like a good thing, I think people still worry about the long-term effects, even after decriminalization. I mean, a marijuana charge can still affect job prospects and other things, which can be pretty bad.

However, there's another side to this. Arresting and prosecuting people for marijuana possession is expensive. It costs a lot to bring them in, house them, and then let them go. Plus, there's the cost of court appearances, public defenders, and other expenses. When a city is financially struggling, they might not be willing to give up that money, even if it would free up some funds for other things.

Denver's a bit of an exception, though. People there tend to be more open-minded and willing to try new things. And I think that's worked out okay for them, as they've been able to use the saved money for education, social programs, and other good causes.

Of course, there are still valid reasons not to have marijuana everywhere. I'm not sure how I'd feel if it was totally legalized, to be honest. I mean, it could be sold in gas stations like cigarettes, and people might start smoking and driving, which wouldn't be great. Plus, it's still not really accepted in many places, so having it out in the open might be awkward.

I also think that marijuana can have some pretty significant effects on people's lifestyles, even if it doesn't necessarily affect their decision-making skills as much as alcohol does. But, like with anything, people react differently, and some folks are just more... let's say, resilient than others. So, it's hard to make general statements about the substance.

Anyway, that's my two cents on the matter.

So, I'd say yes to the idea of adapting certain traditional practices, considering they've been followed for a long time. It's good to have some roots in tradition, but it's also essential to be open to change. The thing is, a lot of Catholics believe in sticking to their weekly church attendance and being very strict about their practices. However, it often feels like they look down on those who don't follow their doctrine to the letter, and they don't accept people with different beliefs or those from other religions.

For instance, my parents are a good example - my mom was Catholic, and my dad was Episcopalian. They wanted to get married in the Catholic Church, but they weren't allowed to because of my dad's religion. This seems contradictory to the Catholic teaching of loving others, which is a fundamental principle. It's hypocritical when you say you're supposed to love others but then exclude them because of their differences. I think the Catholic Church often gets stuck on outdated ideas and sticks to them even though they contradict their own teachings.

Regarding the issue of priests being allowed to marry, I'm not sure it would make a difference in the way some priests behave. It's a separate issue altogether. Even if priests were allowed to marry, some might still engage in certain behaviors because it's about the nature of their actions, not their marital status. So, in this case, I'm not convinced that allowing priests to get married would necessarily prevent those issues from happening.

To be honest, I'm still trying to wrap my head around this complex issue. I'm not quite sure which side has the stronger argument, but I do think this is one of the most contentious topics we're facing today. The line between separating church and state, and defining marriage is a tough one to tread without offending anyone. To be honest, I'm still undecided on how to approach it - all I know is that civil unions sound like a good starting point. I'm not convinced that marriage should be seen as a purely government-defined institution, especially since it's often viewed as a sacrament by many people. If that's the case, then why would the government care about what kind of marriage it is? It's just about two people committing to each other, and that's what a civil union is. It shouldn't matter what the government thinks about the type of marriage it is - it's just about two people uniting.

As for gay marriage, it's basically the same thing - two people entering into a civil union. If all the states can come to a logical agreement, then they should push for it to become federal law. However, a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage seems like a drastic measure to me. It's a big issue for some people, but not big enough to warrant amending the constitution. It's not a vital enough issue to redefine the constitution and ban gay marriage. To put it simply, I'm just not convinced that it's worth it.

Honestly, I don't know what to think.

Honestly, I have a bit of a complicated view on homosexuality because I was raised in a Christian home. On one hand, I have a lot of gay friends, which makes it hard for me to take a firm stance against it. However, I still have some reservations about the lifestyle. Despite this, I think it should be legalized and not be a national issue that the president decides for the entire country. I believe that each state should have the freedom to make its own decision on the matter.

I understand that some states are democratic and others are republican, and it's likely that democratic states will support gay marriage. If you choose to live in a state that allows or bans gay marriage, I don't think you should disagree with the decision. It's ultimately up to the individual states to decide how they want to govern themselves.

What I do think is that homosexuals should have the same rights and opportunities as heterosexuals. Given this, I believe that the decision on gay marriage should be left to each state to decide for themselves. I also think it's unfair for the president to impose his opinion on the whole country. I mean, he doesn't live in every state, so why should he decide how each one runs itself? Plus, he's only in office for a limited time, and if a future president decides to lift the ban, it'll just go back and forth. It's better to let each state decide for themselves, as they'll be the ones living with the consequences of that decision.

Here's the issue - I don't want to post right now because I'm trying to figure out how to get my thoughts across, but essentially, I want to talk about Myspace and why I think school officials could have accessed my information on it. I suppose it's a public platform, like a bulletin board where you can post for everyone to see, and that's okay, but what if school officials see it? They could have checked it from home, even if it wasn't associated with the school's name. 

My opinion is that if it means saving lives and keeping students safe, it's okay for them to check, even if it feels like an invasion of privacy. It's their responsibility to prevent school shootings, like what happened at Columbine. If they check Myspace to see if students are doing stuff they shouldn't be, like drinking or smoking, I think that's okay too, as long as it's not just to get them in trouble.

It's easy to express yourself when you're writing, but I guess that's not the point. It's a public thing, and if you post something on Myspace and don't expect to get in trouble, that's a bit naive. I'm worried about posting stuff online because I know it can come back to haunt me. If I post something negative about someone, it could be found later and cause problems. 

If you do something as a college student that's not good, it can follow you later and get you in trouble. Once something's on the internet, it's there forever, and you can't take it back. School officials might not be looking for trouble, but if they find something that helps make the school a safer place, that's okay. They're just doing their job, like teachers who have to prepare for lockdowns and other safety measures.

I guess what I'm saying is that it's a public platform, but school officials have a responsibility to keep students safe, and if that means checking Myspace, that's okay. They're not just trying to catch students, they're trying to prevent bad things from happening. I think that's a reasonable thing to do.

I've been thinking a lot about the war and my initial reaction to it. I have to admit that I was fully on board with it at first because it hit close to home after 9/11. I wanted to see justice served and to create chaos in response to what happened over here. However, I think we got caught up in the emotions of the situation and overlooked the bigger picture. We charged in without a clear plan, and I genuinely believe that backfired on us.

Now, I've done a complete turnaround and I'm strongly against the war. In my opinion, it didn't achieve anything. The people over there are too busy fighting among themselves to pose a threat to us, so our presence is doing more harm than good. The fact that they can't even put aside their differences to work together is quite telling.

Unfortunately, 9/11 has left me with a sense of apathy towards the conflict in the Middle East. I struggle to care about their struggles because their concept of war is so different from ours. They seem to be more focused on driving us out than on improving their own country. I think it's time for us to leave and let them figure out their own problems.

I believe our initial decision to go to war was driven by a desire for revenge and a knee-jerk reaction to the traumatic event. President Bush declared war on Iraq, and while I understand where he was coming from, I think we were ill-prepared for the consequences. We didn't have a clear plan for creating order or establishing a unified front. This lack of vision and unity ultimately led to more chaos and division.

Looking back, I think we should have taken a more measured approach and had a solid plan in place before invading. In the end, I don't believe we're equipped to change the people of Iraq. They've been a complex and fragmented society for centuries, and it's unlikely that we can force them to become something else. Our continued presence is only exacerbating the situation, and I think we're ultimately hurting ourselves by staying.

It's a complex issue, and I don't have any easy answers. However, I do know that we need to reassess our role in the conflict and focus on finding a way out. The longer we stay, the more we'll be contributing to the instability and chaos in the region. It's time for us to acknowledge that we can't stay forever and start making plans for a peaceful exit.
